video.title_en: How a Frog Led to the Invention of Batteries!

summary.text_en: Italian physician and physicist Luigi Galvani published his findings on a startling phenomenon: when he touched a dissected frog's leg with two different metals (like copper and iron), the dead frog's muscles would 'twitch' violently. Galvani concluded, incorrectly but fruitfully, that the electricity was an 'animal electricity' generated *within* the tissue itself. This discovery founded the fields of bioelectromagnetics and neuroscience.
key_points_en: Discovered that metal contact made dead frog legs twitch
Sparked the famous debate with Volta
The word 'Galvanism' is named after him

story.text_en: Galvani's experiments began by chance. An assistant touched a frog's nerve with a scalpel at the *same moment* a nearby 'static electricity' machine sparked, and the leg twitched. Intrigued, Galvani began systematic tests. He found he could get the same effect *without* the machine, simply by touching the frog's nerve and muscle with *two different metals* (like a copper hook and an iron railing). He became convinced the frog's muscle was a 'Leyden Jar' (an early capacitor) storing a vital 'electric fluid', or 'animal electricity'.

fun_facts.text_en: Galvani's nephew, Giovanni Aldini, continued his work with gruesome public demonstrations on the corpses of executed criminals, 're-animating' them with electricity. This directly inspired Mary Shelley to write 'Frankenstein' in 1818.
The English word 'to galvanize' (to shock or excite into action, or to plate metal) comes from Galvani's name.

simple_explanation.text_en: Galvani was dissecting a frog when he accidentally touched it with two different metals. The *dead frog's leg kicked!* He was astonished and thought he had discovered the 'secret of life'â€”an 'animal electricity' stored in the muscle. He was *wrong* (the electricity actually came from the metals), but his mistake was crucial. It inspired his rival, Volta, to *prove him wrong* by inventing the first *battery*. At the same time, Galvani (accidentally) founded neuroscience, by proving that 'nerves' command 'muscles' using *electricity*.

applications.text_en: Galvani's experiment was the first to demonstrate 'bioelectricity'. It showed that the nervous system uses *electrical signals* to communicate commands to muscles. This is the foundation of all modern neuroscience and neurophysiology.

applications.title: ç”µæ±  (The Battery)
applications.text_en: The debate over 'animal electricity' directly spurred Alessandro Volta (`volta_battery_1800`) to prove electricity could be generated *non-biologically*, leading to his invention of the Voltaic Pile (the first battery).

impact.text_en: Galvani's discovery was one of the most sensational scientific events of the late 18th century. Although his 'theory' (animal electricity) was wrong, his 'experiment' was revolutionary. The twitching frog leg launched *two* new fields at the same time: (1) Bioelectromagnetics (how bodies use electricity) and (2) Electrochemistry (Volta's battery).

influenced_by.contribution_en: The Leyden Jar (provided the early model of 'static electricity' being stored and discharged)

influenced.contribution_en: Alessandro Volta (his invention of the battery was a *direct refutation* of Galvani's 'animal electricity' theory)
Modern Neurophysiology (all work on nerve impulses as 'electrical signals' descends from Galvani)

influence_chain.legacy_text_en: Galvani *mistakenly* discovered 'animal electricity', but in doing so, he *correctly* revealed 'bioelectricity'â€”that life itself runs on electricity.

quiz.question_en: When Galvani saw the frog leg twitch, what did he *incorrectly* believe was the source of the electricity?
options_en: A chemical reaction between the two different metals
An 'animal electricity' stored inside the frog's muscle
A spark from a nearby static machine
quiz.explanation_en: While a static machine *started* his experiments, Galvani's final theory was that the electricity ('animal electricity') was a 'vital fluid' inherent to the organism and stored in the muscle. Volta later proved the electricity *actually* came from the contact of the two different metals.
